help.title: Gmail Operator Reference
help.intro: Below are the operators supported by the builder and what they mean in Gmail.

operators.desc: CC = carbon copy (visible). BCC = blind carbon copy (hidden).
Matches attachment name or extension (e.g. pdf, *.docx).
Messages with a custom Gmail label you created.
Messages in a Gmail system folder: inbox, spam, trash, sent, promotions, updates, social.
Filter by star (⭐) or importance (►) status.
Combines two terms so either matches (must be uppercase).
Excludes messages matching the term (NOT operator).
Groups terms so operators apply to the whole group.

tips: Wrap multi-word values in quotes: subject:"quarterly report"
Use OR inside parentheses to match any of several values: from:(a@x.com OR b@x.com)
Gmail operators are case-insensitive, but OR must be uppercase.
Paste the generated query directly into Gmail's search bar or the 'Has the words' field when creating a filter.
Combine newer_than and older_than to target a precise window: newer_than:3m older_than:1m
label: searches your own custom labels. in: searches Gmail's built-in folders (inbox, spam, promotions…).

guide.title: How to apply your filter in Gmail
guide.intro: Once you have built your query with this tool, follow these steps to turn it into a permanent automatic rule inside Gmail.
guide.step1_desc: Click the [Copy] button in the «Generated search» card on this page. The query is now in your clipboard.
guide.step2_desc: Go to gmail.com in your browser and sign in if you haven't already.
guide.step3_title: Click the search bar at the top
guide.step3_desc: Gmail has a wide search bar at the top of the page (it says «Search mail»). Click anywhere on it.
guide.step4_desc: Press Ctrl+V (Windows / Linux) or Cmd+V (Mac) to paste. You will see the query appear in the search bar.
guide.step5_title: Click the Search options icon at the right end of the search bar
guide.step5_desc: Look carefully at the right edge of the search bar — there is an icon represented by three horizontal lines with sliders (Search options). Click it to open the advanced options panel.
guide.step5_tip: This is the step most people miss! The icon is subtle and sits right at the edge. In older Gmail versions it might be a small arrow ▼, but now it's usually this settings icon.
guide.step6_desc: A panel will open showing the search details. At the bottom of this panel, click the button that says «Create filter with this search».
guide.step7_title: Choose what Gmail should do automatically
guide.step7_desc: Tick one or more actions — archive, apply a label, mark as read, delete, forward... then click [Create filter] to confirm.
guide.done: Done! Gmail will now apply this rule automatically to every new matching email — no extra work needed.
